concepts.term: sampling property of the delta function

evidence: system’s response to a delta function
shifting the input shifts the output in the same way - that’s shift-invariance
This operation, convolution, lies at the heart of modeling and understanding them
utilized the sampling property of the delta function
If we shift the delta to t minus tau, the output becomes h of t minus tau.

concepts.term: collecting all the weighted impulse responses across time

evidence: If we shift the input by t minus tau, the output becomes h of t minus tau. In other words, shifting the input shifts the output in the same way - that’s shift-invariance.
Because the system is linear, the output also gets scaled - giving us x of tau times h of t minus tau.
To build the full output for a general input signal, we integrate over all time - summing these scaled and shifted responses.
This is how linear, shift-invariant systems behave in continuous time - and this operation, convolution, lies at the heart of modeling and understanding them.

triples.evidence: Shifting the input shifts the output in the same way - that’s shift-invariance.
